question_text: What are the key uncertainties in the thermochemistry of NCN that impact prompt-NO modeling, and how do these uncertainties propagate to NO predictions in flames?
standard_answer: The heat of formation of NCN (ΔfH°298) is a major uncertainty in prompt-NO modeling, with reported values ranging from 106.1 to 111.1 kcal/mol. This ±2.5 kcal/mol uncertainty significantly affects the equilibrium constants and rate constants of reactions involving NCN, particularly the reverse reaction CH + N2 ↔ NCN + H (R4/R4b) and the branching of NCN + H. A higher ΔfH°(NCN) makes R4 less exothermic, reducing the forward rate constant k4 and thus decreasing prompt-NO initiation. It also shifts the equilibrium of R4b, affecting the recycling of NCN to CH. This uncertainty propagates to NO predictions because the NCN concentration and its reaction pathways control the fixed nitrogen partitioning between NO and cyanides. For example, a 1 kcal/mol increase in ΔfH°(NCN) can alter NO yields by 10-20% in fuel-rich flames due to changes in the NCN + H branching ratio. The recent ATcT value of 107.7 kcal/mol helps reduce this uncertainty, but residual errors in high-temperature extrapolations of thermochemical data still limit modeling accuracy, especially in predicting the transition from NO to HCN dominance under very rich conditions.

original_text.2: The accuracy of the theoretical values is affected by uncertainty in the prediction of the inter-system crossing probability for NCN + H and in the thermodynamic properties for NCN and CH when extrapolated to high temperatures.
